unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities: Solar Rooftop Subsidies See Increased Uptake in Maharashtra**
normalised: Energy and Utilities: Solar Rooftop Subsidies See Increased Uptake in Maharashtra

unnormalised: Mumbai, Oct 26 - The Maharashtra Energy Development Agency (MEDA) reports a significant increase in applications for solar rooftop subsidies in Q3 2023. Driven by rising electricity costs and increased awareness, the state has seen a 40% jump in subsidy requests compared to the same period last year.
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty six - The M E D A reports a significant increase in applications for solar rooftop subsidies in Q three two thousand and twenty three. Driven by rising electricity costs and increased awareness, the state has seen a forty percent jump in subsidy requests compared to the same period last year.

unnormalised: Dr. Arun Sharma, Director of MEDA, attributes the rise to the government's aggressive outreach programs targeting residential consumers and SMEs. Under the scheme, eligible applicants can receive subsidies of up to Rs. 78,000 for rooftop installations covering areas of 500 sq ft or more.
normalised: Doctor Arun Sharma, Director of M E D A, attributes the rise to the government's aggressive outreach programs targeting residential consumers and S M E s. Under the scheme, eligible applicants can receive subsidies of up to rupee seventy eight thousand for rooftop installations covering areas of five hundred square feet or more.

unnormalised: The initiative aims to promote clean energy adoption and reduce reliance on coal-based power plants. Villages like Shirgaon in Raigad district have seen particularly high adoption rates. The government is also partnering with local DISCOMs like Tata Power to streamline the application process. Further expansion of the scheme to cover housing societies and agricultural pumps is under consideration. Officials project an additional 500 MW of solar capacity to be added through rooftop installations within the next 2 years.
normalised: The initiative aims to promote clean energy adoption and reduce reliance on coal-based power plants. Villages like Shirgaon in Raigad district have seen particularly high adoption rates. The government is also partnering with local D I S C O M s like Tata Power to streamline the application process. Further expansion of the scheme to cover housing societies and agricultural pumps is under consideration. Officials project an additional five hundred megawatt of solar capacity to be added through rooftop installations within the next two years.
